column1: The home I had come to as vicar was in a little neighborhood consisting of farmers who tilled their own grounds and were equal strangers to opulence and poverty. As they had almost all the conveniences of life within themselves
column2: they seldom visited towns or cities in search of superfluity. Remote from the polite
column3: they still retained the primeval simplicity of manners; and
column5: they scarce knew that temperance was a virtue. They wrought with cheerfulness on days of labor but observed festivals as intervals of idleness and pleasure. They kept up the Christmas carol
column8: showed their wit on the first of April
column9: and religiously cracked nuts on Michaelmas-eve. Being apprised of our approach
column10: the whole neighborhood came out to meet their minister
column11: dressed in their finest clothes and preceded by a pipe and tabor: a feast
column14: at which we sat cheerfully down
column15: and what the conversation wanted in wit was made up in laughter.
